title: Ultimate Comfort Food Chili (Hearty Recipe)

description: Warm up with this hearty chili recipe that's great for chilly nights! Packed with flavor and easy to make, it's a family favorite. Try it today!
ingredients: 2 cans (15 oz each) kidney beans, drained and rinsed
Optional toppings: shredded cheese, sour cream, chopped green onions
instructions: In a large pot, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add diced onion and bell pepper, sautéing until softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in minced garlic and cook for an additional minute until fragrant.
Add ground beef to the pot, breaking it apart with a spoon. Cook until browned, about 5-7 minutes. Drain excess fat if necessary.
Stir in chili powder, cumin, smoked paprika, salt, and pepper. Cook for 2 minutes to toast the spices.
Add crushed tomatoes, kidney beans, and beef broth. Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low and cover. Let it cook for 30-40 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Taste and adjust seasoning if needed. Serve hot with optional toppings.
tips: Here's the thing: For perfect chili, use a mix of beans for varied texture and flavor. Always taste and adjust seasoning before serving. If you like it spicy, add diced jalapeños or a dash of hot sauce. Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 4 days, or freeze for up to 3 months. Reheat on the stovetop over low heat, adding a splash of broth if it thickens too much. For a richer flavor, let the chili sit overnight in the fridge before serving.

structured_content.content:
Chili is that one pot meal everyone needs to know how to make. Ground beef, beans, tomatoes, spices. Let it simmer for an hour and you're done. Fills you up and warms you up. Perfect for cold nights when you want something hearty without spending all day cooking.

I make chili probably once a month during fall and winter. It's easy, makes a ton of food, and everyone likes it. Plus leftovers taste even better the next day. That's the sign of good chili. When it gets better after sitting in the fridge overnight.

note.label: Why This Works
note.content:
• Done in an hour which is pretty fast for how much food you get
  • Tastes like you cooked all day but you didn't
  • Perfect for feeding a crowd or meal prepping for the week
  • Uses pantry staples nothing exotic
  • Cheap to make and stretches far
  • Actually gets better as leftovers

structured_content.content: First time I made chili was in college. Had a big pot and needed to eat for a week on like twenty bucks. Chili was the answer. Ground beef, canned beans, canned tomatoes. Fed me for days. Still make it the same basic way. Some recipes you don't need to mess with.

This chili became our go to for cold winter nights. Come home from work, throw it all in a pot, let it bubble away while you do other stuff. House smells amazing. Dinner's ready with minimal effort. That's smart cooking right there.

• Ground beef: Get the 80/20 lean. Not too fatty but enough fat for flavor. Don't get the super lean stuff or your chili will be dry. Brown it good for best taste.
  • Beans: Kidney beans are classic but any beans work. Pinto beans, black beans, whatever. I use two cans because beans stretch the meat and make it cheaper.
  • Crushed tomatoes: Big can of crushed tomatoes gives it body. Don't use diced tomatoes. They don't break down the same. Crushed is what you want.
  • Chili powder: Main spice. Don't be shy with it. Two tablespoons is right. Less and it tastes bland. More if you like it spicier.
  • Beef broth: Makes it more soup like instead of too thick. Can use water if you don't have broth but broth tastes better.
  • Big pot: Need something that holds everything. Dutch oven is perfect but any big pot works.

Don't buy the fancy ingredients. This is comfort food not fine dining. Store brand beans and tomatoes work just as good as name brand. Save your money. Nobody can tell the difference once it's all cooked together anyway.

upload.context: Fresh ingredients for chili including ground beef, beans, tomatoes, and spices arranged on a wooden cutting board, ready for cooking.

structured_content.content:
Start by chopping your onion and bell pepper. Doesn't have to be perfect. Just dice them up small enough to cook down. Mince your garlic or use the jarred stuff. Whatever's easier.

Heat oil in your pot. Cook the onion and pepper until they're soft. Takes like 5 minutes. Add the garlic and cook for a minute. Then add the ground beef. Break it up with your spoon while it cooks. You want it all browned. Drain the fat if there's a lot. I usually don't bother if I used lean beef.

Throw in your spices and stir them around for a couple minutes. This toasts them and makes them taste better. Then add the tomatoes, beans, and broth. Stir it all up. Bring it to a bubble then turn the heat down low. Put a lid on it and let it simmer for 30 to 40 minutes. Stir it every once in a while so nothing sticks to the bottom.

Taste it before serving. Add more salt, pepper, or chili powder if it needs it. Everyone's taste is different so adjust it how you like.

The simmering part is important. That's when all the flavors mix together and it stops tasting like separate ingredients. Don't rush this. Low and slow is better than high and fast. Patience makes better chili.

upload.context: Stirring the chili in a large pot on the stovetop, with steam rising and ingredients bubbling.

note.label: Don't Forget
note.content:
• Keep it at a low simmer not a hard boil. Gentle bubbling is what you want.
  • Don't overcook the meat in the browning stage. Just until it's not pink anymore.
  • It's done when it's thick and smells amazing. Should coat a spoon.
  • Keeps in the fridge for 4 days easy. Freezes for months.
  • Reheat it slow with a splash of broth if it got too thick.

structured_content.content: Every time I make chili I make extra on purpose. Freezes great in containers. Then when I don't feel like cooking I pull one out and boom, dinner's ready. Future you will thank present you for making extra. Trust me on this.

Leftover chili is the best. Put it on hot dogs for chili dogs. Use it as taco filling. Eat it over rice. Pour it on nachos. So many options. That's why I always make a big pot. More leftovers means more easy meals later.
Fresh cilantro on top is really good if you like cilantro. I know some people hate it but I think it adds freshness. Chop it up and sprinkle on each bowl. Makes it look nicer too.

Cayenne pepper for heat. Just a little bit makes it spicy without being crazy. Start with like a quarter teaspoon. Can always add more but can't take it out. My husband dumps hot sauce on his but I make the base mild for the kids.
A splash of beer while it's simmering adds depth. Any beer works. Usually whatever's in the fridge. Don't use the whole bottle, just like half a cup. Makes it taste richer somehow. Old chef trick.

Cornbread is classic. Sweet cornbread with savory chili is perfect. I make the kind from a box because who has time for homemade. Slap some butter on it and you're good. Soaks up the chili juice nicely.
Tortilla chips for scooping. Fritos are traditional. Crunch adds texture to the soft chili. My kids love this. Makes it more fun to eat apparently. Whatever gets them to eat dinner.
Simple salad on the side for balance. Just lettuce and tomatoes. Maybe some ranch dressing. Gives you something fresh and crunchy. Balances out all the heavy chili. Makes you feel slightly healthier.

Turkey instead of beef if you want it lighter. Ground turkey works the same way. Tastes a little different but still good. My sister makes it this way and says she can't taste much difference. Saves some calories.

Vegetarian chili with just beans and vegetables. Skip the meat entirely. Add more beans and some diced zucchini or mushrooms. Use vegetable broth. Different but still tasty. My vegetarian friend makes it like this.

White chili with chicken and white beans. Totally different flavor. Uses green chilies instead of tomatoes. Good for when you want something different but still comfort food. Change of pace from regular chili.

note.label: Extra Stuff
note.content:
• Toast the spices in the pot before adding liquid. Makes them smell amazing.
  • Brown the meat in batches if your pot is small. Better crust that way.
  • Prep your toppings while it simmers. Saves time at dinner.
  • Sour cream and cheese on top looks nice and tastes good.
  • Let it sit overnight in the fridge for even better flavor.

structured_content.content: For meal prep make a huge batch on Sunday. Portion it out in containers. Lunch for the whole week done. Way cheaper than buying lunch every day. Plus you know exactly what's in it. No mystery ingredients.

If your chili is too thin, simmer it with the lid off for a while. The liquid evaporates and it thickens up. If it's too thick add more broth. Easy to adjust as you go. That's why chili is hard to mess up completely.

Chili is one of those recipes everyone should know. Easy, cheap, filling, tastes good. Makes tons of food. Freezes well. All the things you want in a meal. Perfect comfort food for cold weather or anytime you need something hearty and simple.

Make a pot of chili this week. You won't regret it. House will smell great, you'll have plenty of food, and everyone will be happy. That's a win all around. Simple food done right is better than complicated food done okay.
